Publications

McGee, B., Blanch, G., & Franchak, J. M. (in press). Adapting the coordination of eyes and head to differences in task and environment during fully-mobile visual exploration. PLoS ONE.
Luo, C., Lat, Y., & Franchak, J. M. (in preparation). Trade-off between eye-head movement and visual working memory. Author Manuscript.
Franchak, J. M., Scott, V., & Luo, C. (2021). A contactless method for measuring full-day, naturalistic motor behavior using wearable inertial sensors. Frontiers in Psychology, 12. https://doi.org/www.padlab.com
Franchak, J. M. (2020). Looking with the eyes and head. In J. B. Wagman & J. J. C. Blau (Eds.), Perception as Information Detection: Reflections on Gibson’s Ecological Approach to Visual Perception (pp. 205–221). Routledge.
Franchak, J. M. (2020). The ecology of infants’ perceptual-motor exploration. Current Opinion in Psychology, 32, 110–114.
Franchak, J. M. (2020). Visual exploratory behavior and its development. In K. D. Federmeier & E. R. Schotter (Eds.), Psychology of learning and motivation (pp. 59–94). Elsevier. https://doi.org/10.1016/bs.plm.2020.07.001
Kadooka, K., & Franchak, J. M. (2020). Developmental changes in infants’ and children’s attention to faces and salient regions vary across and within video stimuli. Developmental Psychology, 56(11), 2065–2079.
Luo, C., & Franchak, J. M. (2020). Head and body structure infants’ visual experiences during mobile, naturalistic play. PLoS ONE, 15, e0242009.
Franchak, J. M. (2019). Changing opportunities for learning in everyday life: Infant body position over the first year. Infancy, 24, 187–209.
Franchak, J. M. (2019). Development of affordance perception and recalibration in children and adults. Journal of Experimental Child Psychology, 183, 100–114.
Franchak, J. M., Kretch, K. S., & Adolph, K. E. (2018). See and be seen: Infant–caregiver social looking during locomotor free play. Developmental Science, 21, e12626. https://doi.org/10.1111/desc.12626f
Franchak, J. M., & Somoano, F. A. (2018). Rate of recalibration to changing affordances for squeezing through doorways reveals the role of feedback. Experimental Brain Research, 236, 1699–1711.
Labinger, E., Monson, J., & Franchak, J. M. (2018). Effectiveness of adults’ spontaneous exploration while perceiving affordances for squeezing through doorways. PLoS One, 13, e0209298.

Gaze in action: Head-mounted eye tracking of children’s dynamic visual attention during naturalistic behavior. Journal of Visualized Experiments, 141, e58496.
Adolph, K. E., & Franchak, J. M. (2017). The development of motor behavior. WIREs Cognitive Science, 8, e1430.
Franchak, J. M. (2017). Exploratory behaviors and recalibration: What processes are shared between functionally similar affordances? Attention, Perception, and Psychophysics, 79, 1816–1829.
Franchak, J. M. (2017). Using head-mounted eye tracking to study development. In B. Hopkins, E. Geangu, & S. Linkenauger (Eds.), The cambridge encyclopedia of child development (2nd ed., pp. 113–116). Cambridge University Press.
Franchak, J. M., Heeger, D. J., Hasson, U., & Adolph, K. E. (2016). Free viewing gaze behavior in infants and adults. Infancy, 21, 262–287. https://doi.org/10.1111/infa.12119
Franchak, J. M., & Yu, C. (2015). Visual-motor coordination in natural reaching of young children and adults. Proceedings of the 37th Annual Meeting of the Cognitive Science Society.
Nayar, K., Franchak, J. M., Adolph, K. E., & Kiorpes, L. (2015). From local to global processing: The development of illusory contour perception. Journal of Experimental Child Psychology, 131, 38–55.
Bambach, S., Franchak, J. M., Crandall, D. J., & Yu, C. (2014). Detecting hands in children’s egocentric views to understand embodied attention during social interaction. Proceedings of the 36th Annual Meeting of the Cognitive Science Society.
Franchak, J. M., & Adolph, K. E. (2014). Affordances as probabilistic functions: Implications for development, perception, and decisions for action. Ecological Psychology, 26, 109–124.
Franchak, J. M., & Adolph, K. E. (2014). Gut estimates: Pregnant women adapt to changing possibilities for squeezing through doorways. Attention, Perception, and Psychophysics, 76, 460–472.
Ishak, S., Franchak, J. M., & Adolph, K. E. (2014). Perception-action development from infants to adults: Perceiving affordances for reaching through openings. Journal of Experimental Child Psychology, 117, 92–105.
Kretch, K. S., Franchak, J. M., & Adolph, K. E. (2014). Crawling and walking infants see the world differently. Child Development, 85, 1503–1518. https://doi.org/10.1111/cdev.12206
Comalli, D. M., Franchak, J. M., Char, A., & Adolph, K. E. (2013). Ledge and wedge: Younger and older adults’ perception of action possibilities. Experimental Brain Research, 228, 183–192. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00221-013-3550-0
Franchak, J. M., & Adolph, K. E. (2012). What infants know and what they do: Perceiving possibilities for walking through openings. Developmental Psychology, 48, 1254–1261.
Franchak, J. M., Celano, E. C., & Adolph, K. E. (2012). Perception of passage through openings cannot be explained geometric body dimensions alone. Experimental Brain Research, 223, 301–310.

Franchak, J. M., Kretch, K. S., Soska, K. C., & Adolph, K. E. (2011). Head-mounted eye tracking: A new method to describe infant looking. Child Development, 82, 1738–1750. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-8624.2011.01670.x
Franchak, J. M., & Adolph, K. E. (2010). Visually guided navigation: Head-mounted eye-tracking of natural locomotion in children and adults. Vision Research, 50, 2766–2774. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.visres.2010.09.024
Franchak, J. M., Kretch, K. S., Soska, K. C., Babcock, J. S., & Adolph, K. E. (2010). Head-mounted eye-tracking in infants’ natural interactions: A new method. Proceedings of the 2010 Symposium on Eye Tracking Research and Applications.
Franchak, J. M., Zalm, D. van der, & Adolph, K. E. (2010). Learning by doing: Action performance facilitates affordance perception. Vision Research, 50, 2758–2765.
Adolph, K. E., Joh, A. S., Franchak, J. M., Ishak, S., & Gill-Alvarez, S. V. (2008). Flexibility in the development of action. In J. Bargh, P. Gollwitzer, & E. Morsella (Eds.), The psychology of action (Vol. 2, pp. 399–426). Oxford University Press.
